message_text: Paper Title: Strong Structural Controllability of Boolean Networks: Polynomial-Time Criteria, Minimal Node Control, and Distributed Pinning Strategies Paper Abstract: In this article, we initiate the strong structural controllability of Boolean networks (BNs), in order to cope with the difficulty of identifying intricate nodal dynamics. The derived necessary and sufficient criteria for the strong structural controllability of BNs are checkable in a polynomial amount of time. As an interesting feature, controllability is shown to be equivalent to fixed-time controllability in the network-structure regard. We further explore the minimal strong structural controllability problem of BNs that, reduced from the minimum vertex cover problem of graphs, consequently turns out to be NP-hard. More worthy implications are that our results on the strong structural controllability also serve as the basis to improve several existing approaches to a certain extent. First, the network aggregation subject to the controllability of BNs is provided where the aggregated blocks, except the rooted blocks, are strongly structurally controllable. Second, the pinning controllers are carried out to render an arbitrary BN controllable through node-to-node message exchange in a distributed form while traditional results only check the controllability of BNs with the preassigned controllers. Notably, the time complexity to design such controllers reduces to be only exponential with the maximal in-degree of pinned nodes rather than the node number of networks. As for the stochastic counterpart, upon the equivalence between the asymptotic stability of stochastic BNs and the criteria of strong structural controllability, we also further facilitate the design of distributed controllers to asymptotically stabilize stochastic BNs in probability. "contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.) "survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work) task - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding) method - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction) data - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus) artifact - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9) tool - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope) concept - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory) other - Entities that don't fit above categories uses - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks) proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS: - ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work) - CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new) { "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey", "triples": [ { "name": "Wikipedia Article Title", "relation": "uses|proposes", "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other", "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...", "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)" } ] } FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool: CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do. 1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field. 2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation. 3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia. 4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters 5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py 6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes. When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter: WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"]) This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains. Begin now.

Here are the search results for Boolean Networks:

## Definition and Basics

A Boolean network is a particular kind of sequential dynamical system, where time and states are discrete.(no content)A Boolean network consists of a discrete set of Boolean variables each of which has a Boolean function assigned to it which takes inputs from a subset of those variables and determines the state of the variable it is assigned to.

## Historical Development

The first Boolean networks were proposed by Stuart A. Kauffman in 1969, as random models of genetic regulatory networks but their mathematical understanding only started in the 2000s.

## How They Work

The dynamics of the system is taken as a discrete time series where the state of the entire network at time t+1 is determined by evaluating each variable's function on the state of the network at time t.

## Biological Applications

Boolean networks have been used in biology to model regulatory networks.(no content)Stuart Kauffman was amongst the first biologists to use the metaphor of Boolean networks to model genetic regulatory networks.(no content)Although Boolean networks are a crude simplification of genetic reality where genes are not simple binary switches, there are several cases where they correctly convey the correct pattern of expressed and suppressed genes.

## Network Behavior

A Boolean network can exhibit stable, critical or chaotic behavior.(no content)This phenomenon is governed by a critical value of the average number of connections of nodes.

The first Boolean networks were proposed by Stuart A. Kauffman in 1969, as random models of genetic regulatory networks but their mathematical understanding only started in the 2000s.

## How They Work

The dynamics of the system is taken as a discrete time series where the state of the entire network at time t+1 is determined by evaluating each variable's function on the state of the network at time t.

## Biological Applications

Boolean networks have been used in biology to model regulatory networks.(no content)Stuart Kauffman was amongst the first biologists to use the metaphor of Boolean networks to model genetic regulatory networks.(no content)Although Boolean networks are a crude simplification of genetic reality where genes are not simple binary switches, there are several cases where they correctly convey the correct pattern of expressed and suppressed genes.

## Network Behavior

A Boolean network can exhibit stable, critical or chaotic behavior.(no content)This phenomenon is governed by a critical value of the average number of connections of nodes.

Web search results for query: "Controllability control theory"

Links: [{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Controllability Gramian - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability_Gramian"},{"title":"Network controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_controllability"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Coherent control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coherent_control"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Flatness (systems theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flatness_(systems_theory)"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about controllability in control theory:

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems. Controllability is a fundamental concept within this field.

## Definition

Complete state controllability (or simply controllability if no other context is given) describes the ability of an external input (the vector of control variables) to move the internal state of a system from any initial state to any final state in a finite time interval. If for any initial state x0 and any final state xf there exists an input sequence to transfer the system state from x0 to xf in a finite time interval, then the system is controllable.

More informally, controllability describes our ability to guide a dynamical system from any initial state to any desired final state in finite time, with a suitable choice of inputs.

## Significance

Controllability is an important property of a control system and plays a crucial role in many regulation problems, such as the stabilization of unstable systems using feedback, tracking problems, obtaining optimal control strategies, or simply prescribing an input that has a desired effect on the state.

## Relationship to Observability

Controllability pertains to regulating the state by a choice of a suitable input, while observability pertains to being able to know the state by observing the output (assuming that the input is also being observed).

## Variants

Examples of variants of notions of controllability include: State controllability, Strong controllability, Collective controllability, Trajectory controllability, Output controllability, and Controllability in the behavioural framework.

Links: [{"title":"Stochastic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_process"},{"title":"Stochastic Processes and Their Applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_Processes_and_Their_Applications"},{"title":"Infinitesimal generator (stochastic processes) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinitesimal_generator_(stochastic_processes)"},{"title":"List of stochastic processes topics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_stochastic_processes_topics"},{"title":"Stochastic processes and boundary value problems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_processes_and_boundary_value_problems"},{"title":"Stochastic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic"},{"title":"Smoothing problem (stochastic processes) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smoothing_problem_(stochastic_processes)"},{"title":"Filtering problem (stochastic processes) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filtering_problem_(stochastic_processes)"},{"title":"Continuous-time stochastic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous-time_stochastic_process"},{"title":"Stochastic calculus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_calculus"}]

Here's information about stochastic processes based on the search results:

## Definition and Overview

Stochastic processes are widely used as mathematical models of systems and phenomena that appear to vary in a random manner.(no content)A stochastic or random process can be defined as a collection of random variables that is indexed by some mathematical set, meaning that each random variable of the stochastic process is uniquely associated with an element in the set.

## Examples

Examples include the growth of a bacterial population, an electrical current fluctuating due to thermal noise, or the movement of a gas molecule.(no content)Notable examples include the Wiener process or Brownian motion process, used by Louis Bachelier to study price changes on the Paris Bourse, and the Poisson process, used by A. K. Erlang to study the number of phone calls occurring in a certain period of time.

## Key Properties and Classification

Based on their mathematical properties, stochastic processes can be grouped into various categories, which include random walks, martingales, Markov processes, Lévy processes, Gaussian processes, random fields, renewal processes, and branching processes.(no content)When interpreted as time, if the index set of a stochastic process has a finite or countable number of elements, the stochastic process is said to be in discrete time. If the index set is some interval of the real line, then time is said to be continuous.

## Applications

Stochasticity is used in many different fields, including image processing, signal processing, computer science, information theory, telecommunications, chemistry, ecology, neuroscience, physics, and cryptography. It is also used in finance, medicine, linguistics, music, media, colour theory, botany, manufacturing and geomorphology.

Links: [{"title":"Vertex cover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertex_cover"},{"title":"Vertex cover in hypergraphs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertex_cover_in_hypergraphs"},{"title":"Vertex cycle cover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertex_cycle_cover"},{"title":"Edge cover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edge_cover"},{"title":"Path cover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Path_cover"},{"title":"Set cover problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_cover_problem"},{"title":"Clique cover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clique_cover"},{"title":"Feedback vertex set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_vertex_set"},{"title":"Kernelization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernelization"},{"title":"Odd cycle transversal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odd_cycle_transversal"}]

## Vertex Cover Problem

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the Vertex Cover problem:

### Definition

In graph theory, a vertex cover (sometimes node cover) of a graph is a set of vertices that includes at least one endpoint of every edge of the graph.

### Computational Complexity

In computer science, the problem of finding a minimum vertex cover is a classical optimization problem that is NP-hard, so it cannot be solved by a polynomial-time algorithm if P ≠ NP.(no content)Its decision version was one of Karp's 21 NP-complete problems and is therefore a classical NP-complete problem in computational complexity theory.

### Special Cases

The problem becomes tractable for certain graph classes:

- For bipartite graphs, the equivalence between vertex cover and maximum matching allows the bipartite vertex cover problem to be solved in polynomial time.
- For tree graphs, an algorithm finds a minimal vertex cover in polynomial time by finding the first leaf in the tree and adding its parent to the minimal vertex cover, then deleting the leaf and parent and all associated edges and continuing repeatedly until no edges remain in the tree.

### Approximation Algorithms

It has several simple 2-factor approximations.(no content)One can find a factor-2 approximation by repeatedly taking both endpoints of an edge into the vertex cover, then removing them from the graph, or by finding a maximal matching M with a greedy algorithm and constructing a vertex cover consisting of all endpoints of the edges in M.

### Parameterized Complexity

The vertex cover problem is fixed-parameter tractable and a central problem in parameterized complexity theory.

## Vertex Cover Problem

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the Vertex Cover problem:

### Definition

In graph theory, a vertex cover (sometimes node cover) of a graph is a set of vertices that includes at least one endpoint of every edge of the graph.

### Computational Complexity

In computer science, the problem of finding a minimum vertex cover is a classical optimization problem that is NP-hard, so it cannot be solved by a polynomial-time algorithm if P ≠ NP.(no content)Its decision version was one of Karp's 21 NP-complete problems and is therefore a classical NP-complete problem in computational complexity theory.

### Special Cases

The problem becomes tractable for certain graph classes:

- For bipartite graphs, the equivalence between vertex cover and maximum matching allows the bipartite vertex cover problem to be solved in polynomial time.
- For tree graphs, an algorithm finds a minimal vertex cover in polynomial time by finding the first leaf in the tree and adding its parent to the minimal vertex cover, then deleting the leaf and parent and all associated edges and continuing repeatedly until no edges remain in the tree.

### Approximation Algorithms

It has several simple 2-factor approximations.(no content)One can find a factor-2 approximation by repeatedly taking both endpoints of an edge into the vertex cover, then removing them from the graph, or by finding a maximal matching M with a greedy algorithm and constructing a vertex cover consisting of all endpoints of the edges in M.

### Parameterized Complexity

The vertex cover problem is fixed-parameter tractable and a central problem in parameterized complexity theory.

Web search results for query: "Stability theory dynamical systems"

Links: [{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"},{"title":"Dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_system"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Dynamical systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_systems_theory"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Structural stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_stability"},{"title":"Lagrange stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrange_stability"},{"title":"Linear stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_stability"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of stability theory in dynamical systems:

## Definition and Scope

Stability theory addresses the stability of solutions of differential equations and of trajectories of dynamical systems under small perturbations of initial conditions.(no content)Many parts of the qualitative theory of differential equations and dynamical systems deal with asymptotic properties of solutions and the trajectories—what happens with the system after a long period of time.

## Key Questions

Stability theory addresses the following questions: Will a nearby orbit indefinitely stay close to a given orbit? Will it converge to the given orbit?

## Methods and Analysis

Under favorable circumstances, the question may be reduced to a well-studied problem involving eigenvalues of matrices. A more general method involves Lyapunov functions.

For equilibrium points specifically, at each equilibrium of a smooth dynamical system with an n-dimensional phase space, there is a certain n×n matrix A whose eigenvalues characterize the behavior of the nearby points. More precisely, if all eigenvalues are negative real numbers or complex numbers with negative real parts then the point is a stable attracting fixed point, and the nearby points converge to it at an exponential rate.

## Historical Development

Aleksandr Lyapunov developed many important approximation methods. His methods, which he developed in 1899, make it possible to define the stability of sets of ordinary differential equations. He created the modern theory of the stability of a dynamical system.

## Types of Stability

Several different stability concepts are used in dynamical systems, including Lyapunov stability or structural stability.

Links: [{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Control loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_loop"},{"title":"Negative feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_feedback"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Open-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-loop_controller"},{"title":"Servomechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Servomechanism"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about control system feedback:

## What is Control System Feedback?

A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.(no content)The name comes from the information path in the system: process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.

## How Feedback Systems Work

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, or SP-PV error, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Key Characteristics

Control systems that include some sensing of the results they are trying to achieve are making use of feedback and can adapt to varying circumstances to some extent. In contrast, open-loop control systems do not make use of feedback, and run only in pre-arranged ways.

## Advantages of Feedback Control

Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example above) guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

## Types of Feedback

Positive feedback occurs if the signal feedback from output is in phase with the input signal. Negative feedback occurs if the signal feedback is out of phase by 180° with respect to the input signal.

A practical example is cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

Perfect! I've successfully completed all the tasks. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** `contribution`

The paper is a contribution paper because it:
- Proposes new criteria for strong structural controllability of Boolean networks
- Initiates a new research direction
- Develops distributed pinning control strategies
- Extends existing approaches and methodologies

**Extracted Triples (6 entities):**

1. **Boolean network** (concept) - Used as the core domain for studying controllability
2. **Controllability** (concept) - Proposed as new strong structural controllability criteria
3. **Vertex cover** (concept) - Used as the basis for understanding NP-hardness of minimal control
4. **Stochastic process** (concept) - Used in extending results to stochastic networks
5. **Stability theory** (concept) - Used for analyzing asymptotic stability
6. **Control system** (concept) - Used as the foundation for developing pinning control strategies

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the JSON validation passed successfully.

Sources:
- [Boolean network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_network)

- [Vertex cover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertex_cover)

- [Stability theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory)
- [Control system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system)
